The image of the Latina woman often is not in the business world but in the domestic.<ref name="Cofer 1993" /> The sexualization of Latina women sexualizes the positions that they are expected to occupy. Domestic servants, maids, and waitresses are the typical "media-engendered" roles that make it difficult for Latinas to gain "upward mobility" despite the fact that many hold PhDs.<ref name="Cofer 1993" />
== American Psychological Association view ==
=== Definition === The [[American Psychological Association]] (APA) in its 2007 Report looked at the cognitive and emotional consequences of sexualization and the consequences for mental and physical health, and impact on development of a healthy sexual self-image.<ref name=APA /> The report considers that a person is sexualized in the following situations: *a person's value comes only from his or her [[Sexual attraction|sexual appeal]] or [[Human sexual behavior|sexual behavior]], to the exclusion of other characteristics; *a person is held to a standard that equates [[physical attractiveness]] (narrowly defined) with being sexy; *a person is [[sexual objectification|sexually objectified]]—that is, made into a thing for others' sexual use, rather than seen as a person with the capacity for independent action and decision making; and/or *sexuality is inappropriately imposed upon a person.<ref name=APA />
=== Children === Some [[cultural critic]]s have postulated that over recent decades children have evidenced a level of sexual knowledge or sexual behaviour inappropriate for their age group.<ref>{{cite book | last = Kaeser | first = Fred | title = Towards a better understanding of children's sexual behavior | url = https://www.psychologytoday.com/files/attachments/74965/towardsabetterunderstandingofchildrenssexualbehavior.pdf | format = pdf | publisher = NYU Child Study Center | date = 30 October 2001 | quote = We know that exposure to sexualized messages, particularly those that are incomprehensible, can have several effects on children. }} ''Fred Kaeser Ed.D. is the Director of Health Services for Community School District Two, NYC.''</ref>
The causes of this premature sexualization that have been cited include portrayals in the media of sex and related issues, especially in media aimed at children; the marketing of products with sexual connotations to children, including clothing;<ref>{{cite news | last = Chambers | first = Suzanna | title = Outrage as Argos sells G-strings for children | url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/pages/live/articles/news/news.html?in_article_id=109621&in_page_id=1770) | work = [[The Mail on Sunday|Mail on Sunday]] | publisher = [[DMG Media]] | date = 14 April 2002 | accessdate = 22 February 2007 | quote = High Street chain Argos has been branded irresponsible for promoting a range of sexually provocative lingerie designed for primary schoolgirls. }}</ref> the lack of parental oversight and [[discipline]]; access to adult culture via the internet; and the lack of comprehensive school [[sex education]] programs.<ref name=APA /><ref name=Lamb_Therapy>{{cite book | last = Lamb | first = Sharon | author-link1 = Sharon Lamb | title = Sex, therapy, and kids: addressing their concerns through talk and play | publisher = W.W. Norton & Co | location = New York | year = 2006 | isbn = 9780393704792 }}</ref>
For girls and young women in particular, the APA reports that studies have found that sexualization has a negative impact on their "[[self-image]] and healthy development".<ref name=APA />
The APA cites the following as advertising techniques that contribute to the sexualization of girls:<ref name=APA /> *Including girls in ads with sexualized women wearing matching clothing or posed seductively. *Dressing girls up to look like adult women. *Dressing women down to look like young girls. *The employment of youthful celebrity adolescents in highly sexual ways to promote or endorse products. The APA additionally further references the teen magazine market by citing a study by [[Donald F. Roberts|Roberts]] ''et al'' that found that "47% of 8- to 18-year-old [girls] reported having read at least 5 minutes of a magazine the previous day."<ref name="APA" /><ref>{{cite report |last1= Roberts |first1= Donald F. |last2= Foehr |first2= Ulla G. |last3= Rideout |first3= Victoria | author-link1 = Donald F. Roberts | date = March 2005 | title = Generation M: media in the lives of 8-18 year olds | url = http://kff.org/other/generation-m-media-in-the-lives-of/ | publisher = [[Kaiser Family Foundation]] | location = Menlo Park, California }} [https://kaiserfamilyfoundation.files.wordpress.com/2013/01/generation-m-media-in-the-lives-of-8-18-year-olds-report.pdf Pdf.]</ref> A majority of these magazines focused on a theme of presenting oneself as sexually desirable to men, a practice which is called "costuming for seduction" in a study by Duffy and Gotcher.<ref name="APA" /><ref>{{Cite journal |last1= Duffy |first1= Margaret |last2= Gotcher |first2= J. Micheal | title = Crucial advice on how to get the guy: the rhetorical vision of power and seduction in the teen magazine ''YM'' | journal = [[Journal of Communication Inquiry]] | volume = 20 | issue = 1 | page = 38 | date = April 1996 | url = http://jci.sagepub.com/content/by/year | ref = harv}} [https://www.researchgate.net/publication/281903852_Crucial_Advice_on_How_to_Get_the_Guy ResearchGate pdf].</ref>
==== Cognitive and emotional consequences ==== Studies have found that thinking about the body and comparing it to sexualized cultural ideals may disrupt a girl's mental concentration, and a girl's sexualization or objectification may undermine her confidence in and comfort with her own body, leading to emotional and self-image problems, such as shame and anxiety.<ref name=APA />
Research has linked sexualization with three of the most common mental health problems diagnosed in girls and women: eating disorders, low self-esteem, and depression or depressed mood.<ref name=APA />
Research suggests that the sexualization of girls has negative consequences on girls' ability to develop a healthy sexual self-image.<ref name=APA />
A result of the sexualization of girls in the media is that young girls are "learning how to view themselves as sex objects".<ref name=Dewar /> When girls fail to meet the [[thin ideal]] and dominant culture's standard of beauty they can develop anxieties.<ref name=Dewar /> Sexualization is problematic for young children who are developing their sexual identity as they may think that turning themselves into sex objects is empowering and related to having sexual agency.<ref name=Kilbourne />
== Products for children ==
Some commercial products seen as promoting the sexualization of children have drawn considerable media attention: * ''[[Bratz]] Baby'' Dolls marketed at 6-year-old girls that feature sexualized clothing, like fishnet stockings, feather boas, and miniskirts<ref name=Dewar /> * Highly sexualized and gendered Halloween costumes marketed at young girls, such as the "sexy firefighter", a costume that consists of a tight fitted mini dress and high heeled boots.<ref>{{cite news | last = Delisle | first = Riana | title = Halloween costumes are sexualizing our youngest trick-or-treaters | url = http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/raina-delisle/halloween-costumes-sexy-inappropriate_b_6006922.html | work = [[The Huffington Post]] | publisher = [[AOL]] | location = Canada | date = 18 October 2014 }}</ref> * Girls aged 10 and 11 wearing thongs in primary school.<ref>{{cite news | last = Staff writer | title = Pupils warned not to wear thongs | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/education/2943874.stm | work = [[BBC News]] | publisher = [[BBC]] | location = UK | date = 28 May 2003 | accessdate = 22 February 2007 | quote = Parents have been urged by a head teacher to stop their daughters wearing thongs to a primary school. }}</ref> * Clothing such T-shirts being marketed for young children in preschool and elementary school with printed slogans like "So Many Boys So Little Time"<ref name=Kilbourne /> * Padded bras on bikinis aimed at seven-year-old girls.<ref>{{cite news | last = Barr | first = Robert (in London) | title = Outrage at girls' padded bikinis | url = http://www.theage.com.au/world/outrage-at-girls-padded-bikinis-20100415-shjf.html | work = [[The Age]] | publisher = [[Fairfax Media]] | location = Melbourne, Australia | date = 16 April 2010 }}</ref> Some people regard [[training bra]]s similarly. However, there is also evidence that with the mean age of puberty declining in Western cultures, functional brassieres are required by a higher percentage of preteen girls than before.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Aksglaede | first1 = Lise | last2 = Sørensen | first2 = Kaspar | last3 = Petersen | first3 = Jørgen H. | last4 = Skakkebæk | first4 = Niels E. | last5 = Juul | first5 = Anders | title = Recent decline in age at breast development: the Copenhagen Puberty Study | journal = [[Pediatrics (journal)|Pediatrics]] | volume = 123 | issue = 5 | pages = e932–e939 | doi = 10.1542/peds.2008-2491 | pmid = 19403485 | date = May 2009| ref = harv}}</ref>
The [[Scottish Executive]] report<ref name=Scot /> surveyed 32 High street UK retailers and found that many of the larger chains, including [[Tesco]], Debenhams, JJ Sports, and [[Marks & Spencer]] did not offer sexualized goods aimed at children. The report noted that overall prevalence was limited but this was based on a very narrow research brief. Whilst this shows that not all High street retailers were aiming products deemed sexualized by the researchers, the research cannot be taken out of context and used to say that there is not an issue of sexualization.{{original research inline|date=September 2015}}
== Culture and media == {{For2|more on the mainstreaming of sex in media and culture|[[pornographication]]}} Sexualization has also been a subject of debate for academics who work in media and [[cultural studies]]. Here, the term has not been used to simply to label what is seen as a social problem, but to indicate the much broader and varied set of ways in which sex has become more visible in media and culture.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Attenborough | first1 = Frederick T. | author-link1 = Frederick T. Attenborough | title = Complicating the sexualization thesis: The media, gender and 'sci-candy'|journal = [[Discourse & Society]] | volume = 22| issue = 6| pages = 659–675 | doi = 10.1177/0957926511411693 | date = November 2011 | ref = harv}} [https://www.academia.edu/7593771/Complicating_the_sexualisation_thesis_the_media_gender_and_sci-candy Online.]</ref> These include; the widespread discussion of sexual values, practices and identities in the media;<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Attenborough | first1 = Frederick T. | author-link1 = Frederick T. Attenborough | title = Discourse analysis and sexualisation: a study of scientists in the media |journal = Critical Discourse Studies | volume = 10| issue = 2| pages = 223–236 | doi = 10.1080/17405904.2012.736704 | date = 2013 | ref = harv}} [https://www.academia.edu/7595022/Discourse_analysis_and_sexualisation_a_study_of_scientists_in_the_media Online.]</ref> the growth of sexual media of all kinds; for example, erotica, slash fiction, sexual self-help books and the many genres of pornography; the emergence of new forms of sexual experience, for example instant message or avatar sex made possible by developments in technology; a public concern with the breakdown of consensus about regulations for defining and dealing with obscenity; the prevalence of scandals, controversies and panics around sex in the media.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Attwood | first = Feona | title = Sexed up: theorizing the sexualization of culture | journal = [[Sexualities (journal)|Sexualities]] | volume = 9 | issue = 1 | pages = 77–94 | doi = 10.1177/1363460706053336 | date = February 2006 | ref = harv | citeseerx = 10.1.1.452.7825 }} [http://shura.shu.ac.uk/50/1/fulltext.pdf Pdf.]</ref><ref>{{cite book | last = Attwood | first = Feona | title = Mainstreaming sex the sexualization of Western culture | publisher = I.B. Tauris | location = London | year = 2009 | isbn = 9781845118273 }}</ref>
The terms "[[pornographication|pornification]]" and "[[pornographication]]" have also been used to describe the way that aesthetics that were previously associated with pornography have become part of popular culture, and that mainstream media texts and other cultural practices "citing pornographic styles, gestures and aesthetics" have become more prominent.<ref>{{cite book | last1 = Paasonen | first1 = Susanna | last2 = Nikunen | first2 = Kaarina |last3 = Saarenmaa | first3 = Laura | authorlink1 = Susanna Paasonen | title = Pornification: sex and sexuality in media culture | publisher = Berg | location = Oxford New York | year = 2007 | isbn = 9781845207045 }}</ref> This process, which Brian McNair has described as a "pornographication of the mainstream".<ref name=McNair>{{cite book | last = McNair | first = Brian | title = Striptease culture sex, media and the democratization of desire | publisher = Routledge | location = London New York | year = 2002 | isbn = 9780415237345 }}</ref> has developed alongside an expansion of the cultural realm of pornography or "pornosphere" which itself has become more accessible to a much wider variety of audiences. According to McNair, both developments can be set in the context of a wider shift towards a "striptease culture" which has disrupted the boundaries between public and private discourse in late modern Western culture, and which is evident more generally in cultural trends which privilege lifestyle, reality, interactivity, self-revelation and public intimacy.<ref name=McNair />
Children and adolescents spend more time engaging with media than any other age group. This is a time in their life that they are more susceptible to information that they receive. Children are getting sex education from the media, little kids are exposed to sexualized images and more information than ever before in human history but are not able to process the information, they are not developmentally ready to process it, and this impacts their development and behavior.<ref name=Kilbourne />
Sexualization of young girls in the media and infantilization of women creates an environment where it becomes more acceptable to view children as "seductive and sexy".<ref name=Kilbourne /> It makes having healthy sexual relationships more difficult for people and creates sexist attitudes. Sexualization also contributes to sexual violence and childhood sexual abuse "where 1 in 4 girls and 1 in 6 boys are sexually abused during childhood".<ref name=Kilbourne />
== Criticism ==
The Australian writers, [[Catharine Lumby]] and Kath Albury (2010)<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Lumby | first1 = Catharine | last2 = Albury | first2 = Kath | title = Introduction: children, young people, sexuality and the media | journal = Media International Australia | volume = 135 | issue = 1 | pages = 56–60 | doi = 10.1177/1329878X1013500108 | date = May 2010 | ref = harv }}</ref> have suggested that sexualization is "a debate that has been simmering for almost a decade" and concerns about sex and the media are far from new. Much of the recent writing on sexualization has been the subject of criticism that because of the way that it draws on "one-sided, selective, overly simplifying, generalizing, and negatively toned" evidence<ref name="Vanwesenbeeck2009">{{cite journal | last = Vanwesenbeeck | first = Ine | title = The risks and rights of sexualization: an appreciative commentary on Lerum and Dworkin's "''Bad Girls Rule''" | journal = [[Journal of Sex Research]] | volume = 46 | issue = 4 | pages = 268–270 | doi = 10.1080/00224490903082694 | pmid = 19657946 | date = July 2009 | ref = harv }} * ''A commentary on'': {{cite journal | last1 = Lerum | first1 = Kari | last2 = Dworkin | first2 = Shari L. | title = "Bad Girls Rule": an interdisciplinary feminist commentary on the Report of the APA Task Force on the Sexualization of Girls | journal = [[Journal of Sex Research]] | volume = 46 | issue = 4 | pages = 250–263 | doi = 10.1080/00224490903079542 | pmid = 19657944 | date = July 2009 | ref = harv }}</ref> and is "saturated in the languages of concern and regulation".<ref name="Smith2010">{{cite journal | last = Smith | first = Clarissa | title = Pornographication: a discourse for all seasons | journal = International Journal of Media & Cultural Politics | volume = 6 | issue = 1 | pages = 103–108 | doi = 10.1386/macp.6.1.103/3 | date = January 2010 | ref = harv| url = http://sure.sunderland.ac.uk/6099/1/Smith2010.pdf | type = Submitted manuscript }}</ref> In these writings and the widespread press coverage that they have attracted, critics state that the term is often used as "a non-sequitur causing everything from girls flirting with older men to child sex trafficking"<ref name="EganHawkes2008">{{cite journal | last1 = Egan | first1 = R. Danielle | last2 = Hawkes | first2 = Gail L. | title = Endangered girls and incendiary objects: unpacking the discourse on sexualization | journal = Sexuality & Culture, Special Issue: Sexuality, Sexualization and the Contemporary Child | volume = 12 | issue = 4 | pages = 291–311 | doi = 10.1007/s12119-008-9036-8 | date = December 2008 | ref = harv }}</ref> They believe that the arguments often ignore feminist work on media, gender and the body and present a very conservative and negative view of sex in which only monogamous heterosexual sexuality is regarded as normal.<ref name="LerumDworkin2009">{{cite journal | last1 = Lerum | first1 = Kari | last2 = Dworkin | first2 = Shari L. | title = "Bad Girls Rule": an interdisciplinary feminist commentary on the Report of the APA Task Force on the Sexualization of Girls | journal = [[Journal of Sex Research]] | volume = 46 | issue = 4 | pages = 250–263 | doi = 10.1080/00224490903079542 | pmid = 19657944 | date = July 2009 | ref = harv }}</ref> They say that the arguments tend to neglect any historical understanding of the way sex has been represented and regulated, and they often ignore both theoretical and empirical work on the relationship between sex and media, culture and technology.<ref name=Scot /><ref name=EganHawkes2008 />
The sexualization of women being influenced by society is a problem that should be avoided due to its impact on how women value and present themselves. The way society shapes ones personal interest is presented in a book review of ''Girls Gone Skank'' by [[Patrice Oppliger]],<ref>{{cite book | last = Oppliger | first = Patrice | author-link = Patrice Oppliger | title = Girls gone skank: the sexualization of girls in American culture | year = 2008 | publisher = McFarland and Company Inc. | location = Jefferson, North Carolina | isbn = 9780786435227 }}</ref> Amanda Mills states that "consequently, girls are socialized to participate in their own abuse by becoming avid consumers of and altering their behavior to reflect sexually exploitative images and goods."<ref>{{cite journal | last = Mills | first = Amanda | title = Book review: "''Girls gone skank: the sexualization of girls in American culture''" by Patrice Oppliger | journal = [[Feminist Review]] | volume = 99 | issue = 1 | pages = e16–e17 | doi = 10.1057/fr.2011.45 | date = November 2011 | ref = harv }}</ref> The belief that women are powerful and fully capable as men is stated in the text "Uses Of The Erotic: The Erotic As Power" by [[Audre Lorde]] stating that the suppression of [[The Erotic|the erotic]] of women has led them feeling superior to men "the superficially, erotic had been encouraged as a sign of female inferiority on the other hand women have been made to suffer and to feel opposed contemptible and suspect by virtue of its existence".<ref>{{cite book | last = Lorde | first = Audre | author-link = Audre Lorde | title = Uses of the erotic: the erotic as power | publisher = Kore Press | location = Tucson, Arizona | year = 2000 | origyear = 1984 | isbn = 9781888553109 }} * ''Also available as'': {{citation | last = Lorde | first = Audre | author-link = Audre Lorde | contribution = Uses of the erotic: the erotic as power | editor-last1 = Kirk | editor-first1 = Gwyn | editor-last2 = Okazawa-Rey | editor-first2 = Margo | title = Women's lives: multicultural perspectives | pages = 168–172 | publisher = McGraw-Hill | location = New York, New York | year = 2010 | isbn = 9780073512303 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} {{Spanish name|Cazorla|Prieto}} [[File:Soledad Cazorla Prieto (cropped).JPG|thumb|300px|Soledad Cazorla Prieto]] '''Soledad Cazorla Prieto''' (19 February 1955 – 4 May 2015) was a [[jurist]] and the first Spanish prosecutor against [[Violence against women|gender violence]]. She directed a network of fiscal specialists who worked in this field in Spain after the creation of the 2004 Integral Law against Gender Violence. She held the position for a decade, from 2005 until her death.<ref name="ABOGACIA_SP">{{Cite web|title=Fallece la fiscal de sala de Violencia contra la Mujer, Soledad Cazorla|url=http://www.abogacia.es/2015/05/04/fallece-la-fiscal-de-sala-de-violencia-contra-la-mujer-soledad-cazorla/|editor=Abogacía Española – Consejo General|date=4 May 2015|accessdate=4 May 2015|language=Spanish}}</ref> Remembered as a defender of equality, her professional career was closely linked to the development of this law.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Cruz|first=Juan|title=Soledad Cazorla, "defensora absoluta de la igualdad"|url=http://politica.elpais.com/politica/2015/05/04/actualidad/1430763991_689103.html|date=4 May 2015|accessdate=4 May 2015|language=Spanish}}</ref>
== Biography == Cazorla was born in 1955 in [[Larache]], then a [[Spanish protectorate in Morocco]], where her family had emigrated at the close of the 19th century. Her father was a military officer of high rank. Her older brother, Luis María Cazorla, is also a jurist. She started her career in 1981 at the Fiscalía of [[Girona]]. In 1984, she moved to [[Valladolid]]. In 1985, she joined the Audiencia Territorial de Madrid, followed by the Inspection Office of the Fiscalía General del Estado in 1993, and afterwards, the Secretaría Técnica.
In September 1996, she was appointed public prosecutor of the High Court, where she gained, between other responsibilities, a public indictment against [[Mario Conde]] in the Banesto case.<ref name="PSOE_FICHA">{{Cite web|title=Soledad Cazorla, primera fiscal delegada contra la Violencia sobre la Mujer|url=http://www.psoe.es/igualdad/news/56943/page/soledad-cazorla-primera-fiscal-delegada-contra-violencia-sobre-mujer.html|date=18 July 2005|accessdate=4 May 2015|language=Spanish}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=La fiscalía pide que se aumente la condena a Conde de 10 a 22 años|url=http://cincodias.com/cincodias/2002/05/07/empresas/1020778807_850215.html|publisher=Cinco Días|date=7 May 2002|accessdate=4 May 2015|language=Spanish}}</ref>
In 2005, she rose to Public Prosecutor in the Section against Violence towards Woman she had proposed to the fiscal general of the State, [[Cándido Conde-Pumpido]],<ref>{{Cite web|title=Real Decreto|url=https://www.boe.es/boe/dias/2005/07/16/pdfs/A25447-25447.pdf|publisher=BOE|date=16 July 2005|language=Spanish}}</ref> and in October 2010, she was re-appointed.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Real Decreto 1369/2010|url=http://www.boe.es/diario_boe/txt.php?id=BOE-A-2010-16556|publisher=BOE|date=29 October 2010|accessdate=4 May 2015|language=Spanish}}</ref> The section formed part of the Observation Against Gender Violence.<ref name="El_Mundo">{{Cite web|title=Muere Soledad Cazorla, fiscal de Sala contra la Violencia de Género|url=http://www.elmundo.es/espana/2015/05/04/55476a3aca4741ed698b4571.html|publisher=El Mundo|date=4 May 2015|accessdate=4 May 2015|language=Spanish}}</ref> [[File:Soledad Cazorla Violencia de Genero.ogv|left|thumb|Intervention of Soledad Cazorla on the Integral Law against Gender Violence in Spain. Niger 2008]] Cazorla participated in international meetings in defence of women's rights (France, United Kingdom, [[Morocco]], [[Dominican Republic]], [[Bolivia]], [[Ecuador]], China or [[Niger]]) as a national jurist, collaborating in publications and articles concerning different matters related with Penal Laws.<ref name="ABOGACIA_SP" />
As a defender of equality, and with a high personal commitment and professional interest in the fight against gender violence, her professional career was closely linked to the development of this law in Spain, especially, in the need to protect children who coexist with the hard reality of violence against mothers.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Soledad Cazorla – Fondo de Becas Fiscal Soledad Cazorla Prieto|url=http://www.fundacionmujeres.es/becassoledadcazorla/soledad-cazorla/|work=fundacionmujeres.es|accessdate=19 February 2016|language=Spanish}}</ref>
Cazorla was married to the journalist Joaquín Tagar and had 3 children.<ref>{{Cite web|title=El PSOE destaca la "infalible labor" de Soledad Cazorla para acabar con la violencia contra la mujer|url=http://www.teinteresa.es/espana/PSOE-infalible-Soledad-Cazorla-violencia_0_1351066352.html|publisher=Europa Press|accessdate=4 May 2015|language=Spanish}}</ref> She died of stroke in Madrid on 4 May 2015 .
== Recognition == [[File:Soledad_Cazorla_Niger_2008.jpg|right|thumb|250x250px|Photograph during a trip to Niger in 2008 for the celebration of the Third Meeting of Spanish and African women.]] * 2014: Medal of Honour from the School of Lawyers of Madrid.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Muere Soledad Cazorla, fiscal y pionera en la lucha de la violencia contra la mujer|url=http://www.eldiario.es/sociedad/Muere-Soledad-Cazorla-pionera-violencia_0_384262412.html|publisher=El Diario|date=4 May 2015|accessdate=4 May 2015|language=Spanish}}</ref> * November 2008: recognition of her work in the fight against Gender Violence awarded by the [[Ministry of Equality (Spain)|Ministry of Equality]]. * October 2015, inaugurated of the third Summit of Women Jurists * February 2016, the XI Edition of the Prizes of the Observatory against the domestic Violence and of gender 2016, were allocated to recognise her work.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Homenaje de los XI Premiso del Observatorio contra la Violencia Doméstica y de Género – Fondo de Becas Fiscal Soledad Cazorla Prieto|url=http://www.fundacionmujeres.es/becassoledadcazorla/homenaje-de-los-xi-premiso-del-observatorio-contra-la-violencia-domestica-y-de-genero/|work=fundacionmujeres.es|accessdate=19 February 2016|language=Spanish}}</ref> * February 2016, a scholarship fund was created for the personal development, educational support and life improvement of girls and boys who have lost their mother owing to gender violence.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Presentación Fondo Fiscal Soledad Cazorla Prieto – Fondo de Becas Fiscal Soledad Cazorla Prieto|url=http://www.fundacionmujeres.es/becassoledadcazorla/presentacion-fondo-fiscal-soledad-cazorla-prieto/|work=fundacionmujeres.es|accessdate=19 February 2016|language=Spanish}}</ref>

{{italic title}} In 2006, the [[United States Department of Justice]] alleged in '''''United States v. Ike Brown''''' that the Noxubee County Democratic Executive Committee, in [[Noxubee County, Mississippi]], headed by Ike Brown, had violated the [[Voting Rights Act of 1965]] (VRA) with regards to the county's white minority. The suit alleged that Brown, the chairman of the Committee, had conspired to orchestrate "relentless racial discrimination" against white voters.<ref name="nossiter">{{cite news|first=Adam|last=Nossiter|title=U.S. Says Blacks in Mississippi Suppress White Vote|work=The New York Times|date=2006-10-11|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/10/11/us/politics/11voting.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first=Ari|last=Shapiro|title=White Voters in Mississippi Allege Voting Discrimination|work=National Public Radio|date=2005-11-14|format=audio|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=5011333|accessdate=November 23, 2014}}</ref> This was the first time the VRA had been used to allege discrimination against whites.<ref>{{cite web |title=United States of America v. Ike Brown Noxubee County Democratic Executive Committee |url=https://mscivilrightsproject.org/noxubee/event-noxubee/united-states-of-america-v-ike-brown-noxubee-county-democratic-executive-committee/ |website=Mississippi Civil Rights Project}}</ref>
On June 29, 2007, United States District Judge [[Tom S. Lee]] ruled that Brown (a twice-convicted felon), in conjunction with the Noxubee Democratic Executive Committee, had ''"manipulated the political process in ways specifically intended and designed to impair and impede participation of white voters and to dilute their votes."'' The 104-page opinion held that the Voting Rights Act is a colorblind statute and protects all voters from racial discrimination, regardless of the race of the voter. The Court ruled that the Noxubee County Democratic Party had an illegal intent to discriminate against white voters in violation of Section 2 of the VRA.
The United States entered in a consent decree with the Noxubee County superintendent of general elections, administrator of absentee ballots, registrar, and the county government. The consent decree prohibited a wide range of discriminatory and illegal voting practices, and required these officials to report such incidents if they received information that they were continuing. This consent decree was approved by the district court and filed simultaneously with the filing of the complaint. Brown told ''The New York Times'' that he had not signed any such papers.<ref name="nossiter"/>

{{about||verisimilitude in stories|Verisimilitude (fiction)|other uses|Verisimilitude (disambiguation)}} {{essay|date=January 2012}} '''Verisimilitude''' (or '''truthlikeness''') is a philosophical concept that distinguishes between the relative and apparent (or seemingly so) [[truth]] and [[falsity]] of [[Logical assertion|assertion]]s and [[Hypothesis|hypotheses]].<ref>{{cite web|url = http://web.cn.edu/kwheeler/lit_terms_V.html|title=Definition of Verisimilitude, Carson-Newman University|date=|accessdate=2013-09-23}}</ref> The problem of verisimilitude is the problem of articulating what it takes for one false [[Philosophical theory|theory]] to be closer to the truth than another false theory.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://public.wsu.edu/~campbelld/amlit/realism.htm|title=Realism in AmericanLiterature, 1860-1890, Washington State University|date=|accessdate=2013-09-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url = http://literarydevices.net/verisimilitude/|title=Definition of Verisimilitude, Literary Devices|date=|accessdate=2013-09-23}}</ref>
This problem was central to the [[philosophy of science|philosophy]] of [[Karl Popper]], largely because Popper was among the first to affirm that truth is the aim of [[Models of scientific inquiry|scientific inquiry]] while acknowledging that most of the greatest scientific theories in the [[history of science]] are, strictly speaking, false.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://philosophy.wisc.edu/forster/220/notes_10.html|title=The Problem of Verisimilitude, University of Wisconsin-Madison|date=|accessdate=2013-09-23}}</ref> If this long string of purportedly false theories is to constitute progress with respect to the goal of truth, then it must be at least possible for one false theory to be closer to the truth than others.
==Karl Popper== {{also|Karl Popper#Truth}} Popper assumed that scientists are interested in highly informative theories, in part for methodological reasons—the more informative a theory, the easier it is to test, and the greater its predictive power. But clearly [[Occam's razor|informative power by itself is rather easy to come by, and we do not want to gain content by sacrificing truths]]. So Popper proposed that closeness to the truth is a function of two factors—truth and content. The more truths that a theory [[Logical consequence|entails]] (other things being equal) the closer it is to the truth.
Intuitively at least, it seems that [[Isaac Newton|Newton]]'s theory of motion entails a good many more truths than does, say, [[Aristotle]]'s theory—despite the fact that both are known to have flaws. Even two true theories can have differing degrees of verisimilitude, depending on how much true information they deliver. For example, the claim "it will be raining on Thursday next week," if true, is closer to the truth than the true yet logically weaker claim "it will either be raining next Thursday or it will be sunny".
Popper's formal definition of verisimilitude was challenged since 1974 by [[Pavel Tichý]],<ref>{{cite journal |author=[[Pavel Tichý]] |title=On Popper's Definitions of Verisimilitude |journal=[[The British Journal for the Philosophy of Science]] |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] |date=June 1974 |volume=25 |issue=2 |pages=155–160 |jstor=686819}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=Pavel Tichý |title=Verisimilitude Redefined |journal=The British Journal for the Philosophy of Science |publisher= |location= |date=March 1976 |volume=27 |issue=1 |pages=25-42 |jstor=686376}}</ref> [[John Henry Harris (philosopher)|John Henry Harris]],<ref>{{cite journal |author=[[John Henry Harris (philosopher)|John H. Harris]] |title=Popper's Definitions of 'Verisimilitude' |journal=The British Journal for the Philosophy of Science |date=June 1974 |volume=25 |issue=2 |pages=160-166 |jstor=686820}}</ref> and [[David Miller (philosopher)|David Miller]],<ref>{{cite journal |author=[[David Miller (philosopher)|David Miller]] |title=Popper's Qualitative Theory of Verisimilitude |journal=The British Journal for the Philosophy of Science |date=June 1974 |volume=25 |issue=2 |pages=166–177 |jstor=686821}}</ref> who argued that Popper's definition has an [[unintended consequences|unintended consequence]]: that no false theory can be closer to the truth than another. Popper himself stated: "I accepted the criticism of my definition within minutes of its presentation, wondering why I had not seen the mistake before."<ref>{{cite book |author=[[Karl Popper]] |editor=[[W. W. Bartley III]] |title=Realism and the Aim of Science. From the Postcript to the Logic of Scientific Discovery |url=https://books.google.com/?id=tlowU8nS2ygC&printsec=frontcover |year=2013 |origyear=[https://books.google.com/?id=4L6GswEACAAJ 1983] |publisher=[[Routledge]] |location=[[Abingdon-on-Thames]] |isbn=1-1358-5895-0 |id={{ISBN|978-1-135-85895-7}} |page=[https://books.google.com/?id=tlowU8nS2ygC&pg=PR36&dq=%22I+accepted+the+criticism+of+my+definition+within+minutes+of+its+presentation,+wondering+why+I+had+not+seen+the+mistake+before%22 xxxvi]}}</ref> This result gave rise to a search for an account of verisimilitude that did not deem progress towards the truth an impossibility.
==Post-Popperian theories==
Some of the new theories (e.g. those proposed by David Miller and by [[Theo Kuipers]]) build on Popper's approach, guided by the notion that truthlikeness is a function of a truth factor and a content factor. Others (e.g. those advanced by {{ill|Gerhard Schurz|de}} in collaboration with {{ill|Paul Weingartner|de}}, by Mortensen, and by [[Ken Gemes]]) are also inspired by Popper's approach but locate what they believe to be the error of Popper's proposal in his overly generous notion of content, or consequence, proposing instead that the consequences that contribute to closeness to truth must be, in a technical sense, "relevant". A different approach (already proposed by [[Pavel Tichý|Tichý]] and {{ill|Risto Hilpinen|fi}} and developed especially by [[Ilkka Niiniluoto]] and [[Graham Oddie]]) takes the "likeness" in truthlikeness literally, holding that a proposition's likeness to the truth is a function of the overall likeness to the actual world of the possible worlds in which the proposition would be true. An attempt to use the notion of point-free metric space is proposed by Giangiacomo Gerla.<ref>{{cite book|first=Graham |last=Oddie|title= Truthlikeness|work=Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy|url= http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/truthlikeness/}}</ref> There is currently a debate about whether or to what extent these different approaches to the concept are compatible.<ref> Zwart, S. D., and Franssen, M.: An impossibility theorem for verisimilitude. ''Synthese'', '''158''':1 (2007), 75–92.</ref><ref> Oddie, Graham (2013). The content, consequence and likeness approaches to verisimilitude: compatibility, trivialization, and underdetermination. ''Synthese'' '''190''' (9):1647-1687.</ref><ref> Gerla, G., 2007, "Point free geometry and verisimilitude of theories", Journal of Philosophical Logic, 36: 707–733.</ref>
==Methodology== Another problem in Popper's theory of verisimilitude is the connection between truthlikeness as the goal of scientific progress, on the one hand, and methodology, on the other hand, as the ways in which we can to some extent ensure that scientific research actually approaches this goal.{{fact|date=April 2012}} Popper conceived of his definition as a justification of his own preferred methodology: [[falsificationism]], in the following sense: suppose theory A is closer to the truth than theory B according to Popper's qualitative definition of verisimilitude; in this case, we will (or should, if that definition had been logically sound) have that all true consequences of B (ie: all predicted consequences of theory B's mathematical and physical predictions subject to a particular set of initial conditions) are consequences of [theory] A (['s] similarly predicted consequences – i.e., informally, B ≤ A), and that all false consequences of A are consequences of B (in that those set of events deemed impossible by theory A are a subset of those events deemed impossible B, subject to the same initial data conditions for both – i.e., informally, ¬B ≥ ¬A, so that ¬A ≤ ¬B); this means that, if A and B are so related, then it should be the case that all ''known'' false [[Empirical research|empirical]] consequences of A also follow from B, and all ''known'' true empirical consequences of B do follow from A. So, if A were closer to the truth than B, then A should be better [[Corroboration|corroborated]] than B by any possible amount of [[empirical evidence]]. Lastly, this easy theorem allows interpretation of the fact that A is actually better corroborated than B as a ''corroboration of the hypothesis'' (or 'meta-hypothesis') that A is more verisimilar than B.

{{Infobox Chinese |title=Yan Xing |c=鄢醒 |p=Yān Xǐng |showorder=stp |w=Yan<sup>1</sup> Xing<sup>3</sup> }}
{{Chinese name|[[Yan (surname)|Yan]]}}
'''Yan Xing''' ([[Chinese characters]]: 鄢醒, born 1986)<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url=https://artfacts.net/artist/yan-xing/271851|title=Yan Xing|last=|first=|date=|website=ArtFacts.net|publisher=|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=21 July 2018}}</ref> is an artist known for performance, installation, video and photography. He grew up in Chongqing and currently lives and works in [[Beijing]] and [[Los Angeles]].<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.artforum.com/interviews/yan-xing-discusses-his-solo-exhibition-in-lucerne-45451|title=Yan Xing|last=Campbell|first=Andy|date=|website=artforum.com|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-21}}</ref>
== Early life and education == Yan Xing was born in Chongqing in 1986.<ref name=":0" /> He studied at the Oil Painting Department of Sichuan Fine Arts Institute from 2005 to 2009. After receiving his B.A., he moved to Beijing.<ref name=":0" />
== Artistic career == Yan Xing is known for his interdisciplinary projects which have built a complex, compelling body of work that reflects critically on how history is manufactured today. He interrogates literature, history, and history of art. His work explores themes of negativity, resistance and order and the complexity of their connectivity.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kadist.org/people/yan-xing-2/|title=Yan Xing|last=|first=|date=|website=kadist.org|language=en-CA|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=21 July 2018}}</ref> Yan Xing’s works involve an extremely broad range of media, including performance, video, photography, installation, and painting, among others.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.artforum.com/print/201605/openings-yan-xing-59537|title=Opening: Yan Xing|last=Dillon|first=Brian|date=|website=artforum.com|publisher=Artforum|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=21 July 2018}}</ref>
Yan Xing’s career in art began with ''Daddy Project'' (2011),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://artreview.com/features/2015_futuregreat_yan_xing/|title=2015 Future Great artist|last1=Lin|first1=Aimee|date=|website=artreview.com|publisher=ArtReview|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=21 July 2018}}</ref> it was an hour-long performance he gave an account of his absent “father”. The work was first performed in a group exhibition curated by [[Carol Yinghua Lu]], art critic [[Holland Cotter]] wrote in the [[The New York Times|New York Times]]: “First-person public exposure of a personal life, particularly related to family, is relatively rare in China, and Mr. Yan has become a controversial star.”<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/29/arts/design/in-a-perfect-world.html|title=‘IN A PERFECT WORLD’|last=Cotter|first=Holland|date=2011-04-28|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-07-21|language=en}}</ref> The first institutional solo exhibition of his works was held on 2012 at [[Chinese Arts Centre]], Manchester, UK;<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://archive.cfcca.org.uk/index.php/Detail/occurrences/485|title=Yan Xing's exhibition, 1 November - 8 December 2012|last=|first=|date=|website=Centre for Chinese Contemporary Art (CFCCA) Archive and Library|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-22}}</ref> On 2016, his first solo exhibition in America opened at [[Eli and Edythe Broad Art Museum]] at Michigan State University in East Lansing, Michigan.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://www.broadmuseum.msu.edu/exhibitions/yan-xing|title=Yan Xing|last=|first=|date=|website=Eli and Edythe Broad Art Museum at Michigan State University|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-21}}</ref> From June 2 through August 27, 2017, the [[Kunsthalle Basel]] presented ''Yan Xing: Dangerous Afternoon'', curated by Elena Filipovic, this was the artist's first institutional solo exhibition in Switzerland.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://moussemagazine.it/yan-xing-adam-jasper-2017/|title=A Dangerous Afternoon: Yan Xing|last=|first=|date=|website=moussemagazine.it|publisher=Mousse|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=21 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://artdaily.com/news/96399/Kunsthalle-Basel-opens-exhibition-of-works-by-Yan-Xing#.W1PXli2ZM6g|title=Kunsthalle Basel opens exhibition of works by Yan Xing|last=|first=|date=|website=artdaily.org|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-22}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.artnews.com/2017/08/18/yan-xing-at-kunsthalle-basel-switzerland/|title=Yan Xing at Kunsthalle Basel, Switzerland|last=|first=|date=2017-08-18|website=ARTnews|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-22}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://www.artnews.com/2017/05/10/summer-preview-museum-shows-and-biennials-around-the-world/|title=Summer Preview: Museum Shows and Biennials Around the World|last=|first=|date=2017-05-10|website=ARTnews|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-22}}</ref>
Yan Xing has exhibited and performed extensively, at institutions such as the [[Stedelijk Museum Amsterdam]];<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.flashartonline.com/article/a-taste-for-absence/|title=A Taste for Absence|last=Shen|first=Boliang|date=2017-08-25|work=Flash Art|access-date=2018-07-21|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.e-flux.com/announcements/8859/yan-xing-performance-of-a-massacre/|title=Yan Xing: Performance of a Massacre|last=|first=|date=|website=e-flux.com|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-22}}</ref><ref name=":3" /> [[Contemporary Arts Museum Houston]];<ref name=":5">{{Cite news|url=http://www.aaa-a.org/events/unfinished-country-new-video-from-china/|title=Perspectives 180 – Unfinished Country: New Video From China|date=2012-10-18|work=Asia Art Archive in America|access-date=2018-07-22|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name=":6" /> [[Ullens Center for Contemporary Art]] (UCCA), Beijing; OCT Contemporary Art Terminal (OCAT), Shenzhen and the [[Power Station of Art]], Shanghai. He has also been featured at 7th Shenzhen Sculpture Biennale (2012);<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://frieze.com/article/7th-shenzhen-sculpture-biennale|title=7th Shenzhen Sculpture Biennale|last=Ziherl|first=Vivian|date=2012-10-01|website=Frieze|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-22}}</ref> 3rd [[Moscow International Biennale for Young Art]] (2012) and 3rd Ural Industrial Biennial of Contemporary Art (2015).
Yan Xing is both the initiator and a participant of artists’ collective COMPANY.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Yinghua Lu|first=Carol|date=September 2010|title=Little Movements|url=http://yishu-online.com/browse-articles/?417|journal=Yishu|volume= 9|pages=86–100|via=}}</ref> His works have been public collections include: Rubell Family Collection, Miami;<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://rfc.museum/28c-yan-xing|title=Yan Xing|last=|first=|date=|website=Rubell Family Collection|language=en-gb|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-21}}</ref> [[M+|M+ Museum for Visual Culture]], Hong Kong;<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.westkowloon.hk/en/mplus/collection-artists/yan-xing|title=M+ Collection: Yan Xing|last=|first=|date=|website=westkowloon.hk|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-22}}</ref> [[Kadist|Kadist Art Foundation]], Paris; [[He Xiangning Art Museum]], Shenzhen. Yan Xing has also curated exhibitions such as: ''Dream Plant'', Sichuan Fine Arts Institute, Chongqing; ''Mummery'', Art Channel, Beijing; and the ''Fact Study Institute'', Yangtze River Space, Wuhan.
== Exhibitions == === Selected Solo exhibitions ===
* 2017 **''Dangerous Afternoon'', Kunsthalle Basel, Basel, Switzerland<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.kunsthallebasel.ch/en/exhibition/yan_xing_en/|title=Yan Xing: Dangerous Afternoon|last=|first=|date=|work=Kunsthalle Basel|access-date=2018-07-22|language=en-US}}</ref> * 2016 **''Yan Xing'', Eli and Edythe Broad Art Museum, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI, USA<ref name=":2" /> * 2015 **''Thief'', Galerie Urs Meile, Beijing, China * 2013 **''Recent Works'', Galerie Urs Meile, Beijing, China * 2012 **''Yan Xing'', Chinese Arts Centre, Manchester, UK<ref name=":1" /> * 2011 **''Realism'', Galerie Urs Meile, Beijing, China
=== Selected Group Exhibitions ===
* 2017 **''Spectrosynthesis'', Museum of Contemporary Art Taipei, Taipei, Taiwan<ref>{{cite web |title="Spectrosynthesis": contemporary art and Asian LGBTQ issues at MoCA Taipei == Awards == As a young artist, Yan Xing made an impressive result during recent years. He has received several notable awards, in 2012 he won the Best Young Artist Award by Chinese Contemporary Art Award (CCAA).<ref>{{cite web |title=ArtAsiaPacific: Winners Announced At The 2012 Chinese Contemporary Art Awards |url=http://artasiapacific.com/News/WinnersAnnouncedAtThe2012ChineseContemporaryArtAwards |website=artasiapacific.com |publisher=ArtAsiaPacific |accessdate=21 July 2018 |language=en}}</ref> The same year, he was a finalist in the Future Generation Art Prize by Victor Pinchuk Foundation<ref>{{cite web |title=Shortlisted artists for the Future Generation Art Prize 2012 - Announcements - e-flux |url=https://www.e-flux.com/announcements/33513/shortlisted-artists-for-the-future-generation-art-prize-2012/ |website=www.e-flux.com |publisher=e-flux |accessdate=21 July 2018 |language=en}}</ref> and Focus on Talents Project from Today Art Museum.
